DataElement.preferredName: Central Pathology Review Same As Prostatectomy Highest Gleason Score CPTAC Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A response to indicate which documents if the Gleason Score of the submitted sample represents the highest Gleason Score for the prostatectomy specimen.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Central Pathology Review Same As Prostatectomy Highest Gleason Score
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The process by which specimens are sent to a central lab for confirmatory analysis using standardized methods and result criteria in order to minimize inter-reviewer differences thereby improving the accuracy of pathology data._Equal, or closely similar or comparable, in kind or quality or quantity or degree._In the same amount or manner; to the same degree; in the role, function, or capacity of._Surgical removal of part or all of the prostate._A morphologic grade that refers to the highest grade that a malignant tumor can exhibit (usually grade III-poorly differentiated) or to Gleason Score 8-10 in prostate carcinomas._The score derived from universally embraced prostate cancer grading system developed by Dr. Donald F. Gleason in 1977. The system provides a reproducible description of the glandular architecture of prostate tissue to which a pathologist assigns a score depending primarily on the microscopic patterns of cancerous glands and cell morphology. The system correlates well with behavior at the extremes: Gleason 1+1 tumors are the most well differentiated, slowly growing and rarely spread; Gleason 4+5 tumors are the most poorly differentiated, often widely metastatic at the time of diagnosis. In the commoner intermediate grade tumors, however, behavior is extremely variable.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The process by which specimens are sent to a central lab for confirmatory analysis using standardized methods and result criteria in order to minimize inter-reviewer differences thereby improving the accuracy of pathology data.

Concepts.definition: The process by which specimens are sent to a central lab for confirmatory analysis using standardized methods and result criteria in order to minimize inter-reviewer differences thereby improving the accuracy of pathology data.

Property.preferredName: Same As Prostatectomy Highest Grade Gleason Score for Prostate Cancer
Property.preferredDefinition: Equal, or closely similar or comparable, in kind or quality or quantity or degree.:In the same amount or manner; to the same degree; in the role, function, or capacity of.:Surgical removal of part or all of the prostate.:A morphologic grade that refers to the highest grade that a malignant tumor can exhibit (usually grade III-poorly differentiated) or to Gleason Score 8-10 in prostate carcinomas.:The score derived from universally embraced prostate cancer grading system developed by Dr. Donald F. Gleason in 1977. The system provides a reproducible description of the glandular architecture of prostate tissue to which a pathologist assigns a score depending primarily on the microscopic patterns of cancerous glands and cell morphology. The system correlates well with behavior at the extremes: Gleason 1+1 tumors are the most well differentiated, slowly growing and rarely spread; Gleason 4+5 tumors are the most poorly differentiated, often widely metastatic at the time of diagnosis. In the commoner intermediate grade tumors, however, behavior is extremely variable.

Concepts.definition: Equal, or closely similar or comparable, in kind or quality or quantity or degree.
In the same amount or manner; to the same degree; in the role, function, or capacity of.
Surgical removal of part or all of the prostate.
A morphologic grade that refers to the maximum grade that a malignant tumor can exhibit  (usually grade III or IV-poorly differentiated).

The score derived from universally embraced prostate cancer grading system developed by Dr. Donald F. Gleason in 1977. The system provides a reproducible description of the glandular architecture of prostate tissue to which a pathologist assigns a score depending primarily on the microscopic patterns of cancerous glands and cell morphology. The system correlates well with behavior at the extremes: Gleason 1+1 tumors are the most well differentiated, slowly growing and rarely spread; Gleason 4+5 tumors are the most poorly differentiated, often widely metastatic at the time of diagnosis. In the commoner intermediate grade tumors, however, behavior is extremely variable.
